scenario:
Azlin, 38, is a newly-minted equity partner specialising in commercial law at a mid-sized
Singapore law ﬁrm. Her husband Kok Tong, also 38, does investments and trading at a
local bank. The two had recently gotten married in Jan 2020.
On 1 Feb 2020, they moved into a 3 storey landed bungalow they had bought in the Katong
area. The house is one of those nice heritage houses with a long colonial history. It is part
of a cluster of houses designed and built in 1940 by Due South Ltd, now a big listed
Singapore property developer. After the cluster was built, title of the common areas was
vested in the estate’s MCST. Azlin and Kok Tong (henceforth “A&K”) are the third owners
of the house. They ofﬁcially took over ownership on 31 Oct 2019.
Before moving in, they engaged Disastrous Interiors Pte Ltd (“DI”), an interior design
and furniture company, to plan and also implement a series of renovations. This included
building a new wall fountain in their living room (the sort where water ﬂows down along
a feature wall and into a pool). To preserve the heritage feel of the house, A&K asked that
DI construct the fountain on an existing 3-metre long stretch of heritage wall that lined
their living room. DI inserts some water pipes and pumps in the wall to make this happen.
They also add some claddings to the heritage wall. The $300,000 contract between A&K
and DI does not contain any relevant exclusion clause.
A&K’s discussions with DI took place over Nov 2019. From 1 Dec 2019 to 31 Jan 2020,
DI cordoned off the house as a construction site, putting up the usual barriers and warnings,
and carried out the renovations. From time to time DI would invite A&K over to have a
look at the progress, and A&K would give some creative direction and feedback.
Unfortunately for the newlyweds, their new life together was fraught with twists and turns.
Within a month of moving in, they received a lawyer’s letter from one Tom, a 24 year old
photographer who specialises in taking pictures for interior design magazines. On 15 Jan
2020, Tom had passed by the house on his way to a photoshoot. From outside, Tom could
see from over the 1.5m tall construction site fence that a beautifully renovated colonial
house stood behind it. He thus climbed over the fence hoping to take a few pictures. Tom

1. **Duty of Care**: A&K, as homeowners, have a duty to ensure that their property does not pose a hazard to those outside of their premises. This duty generally extends to lawful visitors and in some instances to trespassers as well depending on jurisdiction. The fact that Tom was outside the premises and not lawfully on the property complicates his position.

2. **Breach of Duty**: Whether A&K breached their duty of care depends on whether a reasonable person in their position would have foreseen the risk of harm. Since he trespassed and the accident occurred because of his action of climbing the fence, causation may be challenging to establish solely against A&K.

4. **Damages**: Tom did suffer actual damages—his broken camera and the lost profits from the photoshoot he missed. However, linking these damages directly to A&K's actions may be legally complex given his status at the time of the accident.

Given these considerations, Tom’s claim against A&K might not be strong. Instead, Tom might have a better chance of pursuing compensation under occupier’s liability via Disastrous Interiors Pte Ltd (DI), the company that was remodeling A&K’s property and was possibly in control or management of the premises during the renovation. Yes, A&K have potential intentional tort claims against Hartono. The actions conducted by Hartono fulfill the criteria for several intentional torts, which include trespass, assault, and intentional infliction of emotional distress.

**1. Trespass to Land:**
Hartono's actions of sneaking into A&K’s home uninvited and without permission constitute trespass to land. Hartono repeatedly and intentionally entered A&K's property for the purpose of causing distress and fear, clearly satisfying the elements of this tort.

**2. Assault:**
An assault in tort law is an act that causes another person to apprehend the infliction of immediate unlawful force on his or her person. In successfully claiming these torts against Hartono, A&K would need to demonstrate the intentionality of Hartono’s actions, the absence of their consent to such actions, the connection between Hartono’s actions and the harm suffered, and the extent of the actual damage caused.

In considering whether A&K have any intentional tort claims against Hartono, the focus will be on the nature of Hartono's actions and their effects on A&K. Intentional torts that may be relevant here include trespass, battery, assault, and intentional infliction of mental distress.
